Konrad,

I don't know enough about your design to critique it, yet, but I'm=

familiar with the things that can happen if you try to run all your
tests =
against One Big Concrete Example, as you seem to be doing.

Usually, in the=
se cases, I recommend that a developer try to
custom-build their data in ea=
ch test, using only what they need.  For
example, although a single lecture=
r, single class, and two rooms isn't
enough to test every available case, i=
t's probably enough to feed to a
simple room-assignment test, etc.

In this=
 case, if I find myself making the same chain of calls over and
over, I som=
etimes write convenient factory methods in my test class,
so my tests can l=
ook like:

@Test public void scheduleRoom() {
   Scenario s =3D scenario(le=
cturer("Smith"),
                      schoolClass("Algebra: requires 50 se=
ats"),
                      rooms("Smith Hall 100: 50 seats", "Smith Hall
=
102: 20 seats"))
   assertEquals("Smith Hall 102", s.getAssignments().getRo=
om("Algebra"))
}

Good luck,

   David Saff
